:shipit:
Travis is not yet green on master, so I'm just going to merge this with reckless abandon
I suggest we use the firefox directory as root, and call this repo zipkin-firefox-extension (or something like that). I don't think this plugin will browser-agnostic anytime soon...
@eirslett good point. sgtm
Maybe even dig up the history since before sprsquish made that big-move-commit...
I've moved this ticket along with the source code, see openzipkin/browser-extension#1
@eirslett you're killin' me! mind just filing an issue on that repo to do that? :P
I believe this overlaps with some work that @jamescway did, which is getting superseded by @michaelsembwever's Datastax work
Hopefully some of @jamescway's work for #457 will help alleviate this, but I think this is a separate task unto itself

@AllienPhone I'm not seeing this behavior, can you please confirm it's still broken for you?

Also, what is the command that is being executed originally?

With a clean machine, located in the US, I had no problem executing `bin/collector` locally with today's HEAD of master.

@yuchen99 which SHA1 are you seeing troubles with?
Closing this as a duplicate
@mosesn if this is still important to you, would you mind elaborating on what you mean? What would the ideal acceptance criteria be?

If I want to be able to look at traces which are between 5PM and 7PM today, because there was an incident and I want to investigate it, I can't do that.  If there are 10K traces, and it just gives me 100 uniformly distributed from the past five days, probably very few of them will be in that 2 hour timespan.

@mosesn pls suggest a preferred approach and I'll ensure that the internal twitter deployment of zipkin-web has a default query limit of 100.

ex.

``` scala
  val queryLimit = flag("zipkin.web.query.limit", 10, "Default query limit for trace results")
```
this should be configurable, as there are valid reasons for different defaults. I opened up this to ensure folks can get what they want https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/462
that style works well for me.  I'm not sure that 10 makes sense though–did you guys discuss what your main use cases are at the workshop?

10 was already decided by majority on the other pull request and don't want
to start a bikeshed on that. I just wanted to make sure you can have the
default you want inside Twitter.
What do you mean majority?  I didn't see anybody express a strong opinion other than me and noslowerdna?
Oh, you merged that in?  Why did you do that without discussing it?

rewriting just the traits to interfaces is a small incremental step in a
positive direction.

i'm a fan of small atomic tickets. can we open up a new ticket, an epic,
for "rewrite (core parts) in java"?

## 

Mick Semb Wever
Scandinavia

The Last Pickle
Apache Cassandra Consulting
http://www.thelastpickle.com

We don't have to further discussion about a default value, when it can be
overridden. You are the only person who asserted further discussion was
needed.
You made the case about why you want default to be 100. The originator made
the case about 10 and the act of merging that was seconded by rtyler and
implicitly me.

This is OpenZipkin: we haven't made a rule that we need 100% consensus. Nor
can we force people to discuss something they are not interested in
discussing further.

Resolving this issue will allow you to have the value 100 and if later the
community wants to change the default to 101, we can do that. In the mean
time, we really do have bigger fish to fry.

I agree, a separate issue is best.

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/463

If you've decided unilaterally to ignore discussion, it seems like it would be polite to say, "This is a bikeshed, I don't want to discuss it any further" rather than, "OK, let's open it up for discussion, does anyone else have something to say" and then merging without actually discussing it.

I'm bothered that I thought we were having a discussion about what zipkin is for, and the face it should provide to folks who are new, and I felt like it was signaled to me that it was indeed important (and indeed, someone made a PR about it!) and then there was a total about-face without any real discussion.  The default _is_ important, because when folks try out zipkin, and try to see if it's useful, they'll see the default.
I'm generally in favor of this. For my own understanding, what overlap does this have with [brave](/openzipkin/brave)?

Moses, there was no discussion for 2 weeks, despite an attempt to encourage folks to do so. There was no unilateralism, as two others besides me indicated they wanted the change. I can tell you aren't satisfied; I'm disappointed that I couldn't please you even by raising this issue.

@mosesn I threw a :+1: in on what looked like a pull request that had been stalled, but was completely merge-able..

The questions raised in the pull request:

> A. Why doesn't latency scale linearly with the number of items we're fetching?
> B. What are the main use-cases of zipkin, and which of them should we optimize for?
> C. How much do zipkin users care about latency? What is acceptable?

I think these are great questions to ask and discuss in terms of overall direction for Zipkin, but I do not see them as show-stopper questions for merging a very minor pull request. From the outside-looking-in on a number of projects, it's always encouraging to see my pull requests merged, even if they do spawn subsequent work (like that captured in this ticket). IMO this is important to foster a good community of contributors.

I think this issue is a good example of how to handle things like this. It was a clearly minor change but as has been raised, defaults are important (of course, until this issue is resolved it's not a default so much as a _constant_). That's not something a casual contributor should be deadlocked in, otherwise the project likely will lose them forever.

Personally, I think the best way to answer those questions (A, B, C) is to get releases built and start getting feedback from other users which have not traditionally participated in the project

@adriancole and I resolved our disagreement off-list, and we agreed that my questions on that PR were out of scope for the change.

@rtyler I agree that we should be working to make sure contributors feel welcome, and that being able to merge a PR quickly is a great way to get a contributor excited about the project.  At the same time, I'd appreciate it if we're explicit about why we're not going to address a concern.  I would have deeply appreciated the explanation you just provided on PR 443.

@mosesn duly noted 

![roger that](http://orig15.deviantart.net/1416/f/2009/003/7/0/roger_that_kitty_cat_by_zoegirl101.jpg)

Note, I tried to follow existing convention.. this doesn't mean I love it :)

cc @noslowerdna @mosesn @rtyler

:+1:

I suspect if we do this well, we can provide a future without the need to maintain both zipkin and brave separately.
lgtm, :shipit:
thx for the review!
_[shrug](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ussCHoQttyQ)_
confirmed this works by deploying to a less used zone in prod at twitter
oh yeah.. the syntax I verified is this `-zipkin.web.query.limit=100`
Here's the style of argument that supports this: `-zipkin.web.query.limit=100`

Sounds not great, but thanks for reporting.

What build of zipkin are you running? (Ex are you building off a fork? If
so, which commit?)

One thing that could potentially cause some confusion is that we have different ways of configuring collector/query (with .Scala files) than web (flags). Would it be worth the effort to rewrite to one "universal" method?

There's some confusion about what should actually be rewritten... It would be a lot of effort to port the whole Zipkin code base to Java, just to get rid of the Scala dependency inside query/collector/web.
What we discussed at the workshop was to extract the "Tracer" client from finagle, rewrite it in Java and then use that?
Our use case at FINN was that we wanted to use Zipkin without having Scala in all our ~300 applications. Collector/query/web are 3 projects that are written in Scala anyways (using the Scala ecosystem and maintained by Scala developers) so that's not a problem at all.
I really don't want to see Zipkin rewritten with Spring/Struts/Hibernate etc...

@eirslett I don't think this issue is about rewriting the back-end services (query/collector/web). If we release / package / document these properly I guess they are fine. I agree that there is no reason why these should be rewritten.

I agree that our goal should be to have 1 Java "core" implementation that can be integrated in Finagle and that could serve as a base layer for the existing brave integrations (jersey, resteasy,...).

You can also use [Flume](https://flume.apache.org/). It supports a ScribeSource (I guess like fluentd).  It did not have a Scribe Sink out of the box but you can use [flume-zipkin-collector-sink](https://github.com/openzipkin/flume-zipkin-collector-sink) and I also found [flume-ng-scribe](https://github.com/streamz/flume-ng-scribe) just now.

I used Flume with flume-zipkin-collector-sink as a drop-in replacement for Scribe and it worked well.

It would be nice to have a logstash-compatible data collection pipeline as well. It should be safe to assume that people have something logstash-ish on their servers, if they are building a microservice platform in the first place?

@eirslett Yes, agree. When I initially started integrating Zipkin we were actually using logstash but logstash had no codec support at that time. This is supported as of [version 1.2.0](https://logstash.jira.com/browse/LOGSTASH-658).  So I guess it should be possible now to use logstash with Thrift.

@b can you clarify a bit, is the Scala reluctancy about not wanting the Scala dependencies in their business applications (very understandable) or is it about not wanting to deploy Zipkin at all because Zipkin is written in Scala? (somewhat less understandable)
I know fluentd does "routing pr topic", so you can send "zipkin" messages to zipkin-collector and "log" messages to elasticsearch/kibana. Can we do the same thing with logstash now?

During the workshop there was also the discussion about replacing traits with java interfaces, which is what this issue is a spin-off from.
 ref: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/451

This discussion went beyond that of just avoiding the scala dependency in client libraries, but providing better compatibility within the server-side zipkin stack.

Today it isn't possible to write your own collector or query implementation
with just pure java. This is going to hold us back from building a community of active developers. And indeed we saw @NiteshKant talk about Netflix writing their own Zipkin because the server-side components were all scala.
  ref: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/451#issuecomment-119854512

This ticket needs clarification as to what it involves, and the broader
discussion be cleanly split between simplifying the client-side and simplifying the
server-side.

Taking a look at this it doesn't look like the first step is replacing traits, since most of them reference other scala classes. 

I suspect a right "first step" is to look into rewriting zipkin-common. This then gets us closer to replacing traits with interfaces, and allowing new subprojects in the zipkin server-side stack to be written with just java (which will help attract more developers to the community).

> which will help attract more developers to the community

I'm afraid it could repel some Scala developers though... I can only speak for myself, but I'd much prefer most of (~99 %) the code base to still be Scala, with only a few Java hooks here and there. (Of course with the exception of the instrumentation code that's going into people's business applications, which should be Java-based like Brave.) The difference between rewriting "key interfaces" and "the whole Zipkin domain model" is pretty big, and deciding to rewrite the entire Zipkin core is a different decision altogether, I would say.
I suggest we make some small changes to the Zipkin server-side code so that it's easier to use both from Java and Scala, without having to rewrite all of it to Java.

@NiteshKant could you please clarify a bit what Netflix' point of view is (or was, regarding the choice of reimplementing Dapper in Java)
You explained at the workshop, but clarification is always nice :-) Was avoiding Scala in the business applications the deciding factor, or is/was it very important that the Zipkin applications themselves were also Java?

> One thing that could potentially cause some confusion is that we have
> different ways of configuring collector/query (with .Scala files) than web
> (flags). Would it be worth the effort to rewrite to one "universal" method?
> I noticed the inconsistency too. Refactoring how we do config in general is
> probably due as things have improved in the last few years. Care to open a
> top-level issue on how you think config ought be handled?

I think this is getting to be mailing list worthy, but at any rate, good
discussion.

The big concern is that there are a few people who want Scala+Finagle impl
to persist.

Can we think about brave? How can we permit can those who can't deploy,
feel limited by, or simply don't like Scala to still be a part of zipkin?
Brave happens to have a subset of features.. Would it be that bad to allow
a java server impl (or golang for that matter)?

I'm guessing the solution is keep the code in a different repo, similar to
brave, so that it doesn't threaten those who still enjoy the current
codebase. Would that work?

At Twitter, static config that varies by environment is passed via flags or
in some cases json files. These are set in pants args when running a
process on laptop or in Aurora config.

The most thought in this area has been in Finatra. A part of this was
spinning out a project to address config, as particularly the lack of
testability has been troublesome. For example the most recent apps can be
spawned safely managed by a test lifecycle (embedded).

https://github.com/twitter/finatra/blob/master/inject/README.md

Hope this helps!

Thanks for the help, Travis!

:shipit:

Yes, we want the stack to be friendly to both java and scala implementations.
Java implementations of the server-side stack should be free to be entirely java.

Today zipkin-common is the "interface" that plays a large part in gluing together the different stack implementations. Whether it is rewritten completely to java, or made java compatible, i have no strong opinion to.

I agree that we don't need to spend time right now on rewriting existing scala component implementations to the server's stack, where they are isolated, to java. If we have a true polyglot stack then if people want a particular component in java rather than scala they are free to do so, and this will be a addition rather than a rewrite. The question of what developers and the community prefers delegates simply to what is popular and maintained best.

@adriancole it's still unclear from your post whether you're talking about the client-side or server-side stack? In context of Brave that's just client-side. 

There are two discussions here.

client-side)
  A) removing scala from client-side libraries.
  B) using common java interfaces in the java client library and in the scala client library.

server-side)
 A-1) rewriting key interfaces (eg zipkin-common) to java to allow new stack components to be implemented in either java or scala, or
 A-2) making existing key interfaces (eg zipkin-common) java-fiendly to allow new stack components to be implemented in either java or scala,
 B) rewriting existing stack components from scala to java to attract more developers into the community.

Brave already solves client-side-A for us.
client-side-B is a "nice to have" in my mind.

I don't think server-side-B is so critical right now. The question of what developers and the community prefers should simply delegate to what is popular and maintained best, as long as we're providing a proper polyglot stack. see my comment in https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/451#issuecomment-122296372

Between server-side-A-1 and server-side-A-2 i don't care. Whatever is quickest to implement gets my vote :-)
Well put!

Fwiw, we do have java services at Twitter (ex storage) and of course
services inherited via acquisition are rarely Scala.

Here are some points I have encountered in a recent project to make a
common model across java and Scala (I attempted to abstract some of our
time series processing code used for an alerting system).

The technical issues are daunting, but solvable. Regardless, they need to
be solved in an environment that desires the solution.

On converting finagle shared libraries towards java:
- scrooge finagle java support didn't work. I think eirik may have fixed
  this.
- even if it did, Scala code uses the Scala types generated by scrooge.
- finagle code tends to always return futures, and these are Twitter
  specific futures.
- Twitter libraries tend to have a lot of deps and also one on a specific
  Scala runtime.
- guava conversion seemed to be the only way out, though we know guava
  versions are sensitive for everyone.
- current scala+finagle mix isn't java 8 friendly, so yeah no lambdas

On finagle services vs ones written without finagle (aka share IDL not
libraries).
- when t-mux isn't used, other thrift impls can interop  (Like Facebook
  swift)
- this means you don't have to use scrooge, as you aren't trying to share
  libraries, rather types (or IDL)
- this isn't that different when thinking about how to address Scala 2.12,
  java or another language.

On pushing thrift to an extension
- thrift is often conflated with finagle and by extension Scala in Twitter
  codebases (even ones written in Java)
- by using plain types and not using scrooge, we could open to codec that
  isn't thrift (ex json) and doesn't pull in vast dependency trees that are
  coupled to specific Scala versions.
- since many prefer json or protobuf, this indirection is likely worth
  whatever conversion cost incurred
  - most build systems can run JMH, so we can at least measure that

Hope this helps.

OK I will be more clear.

We can break down this task, but I desire to help those writing
instrumentation or backends not require a tree of deps and interop problems.

Brave partially solves that problem, but this isn't just about what brave
chose to solve. I didn't intend to get us down that path. Bear in mind that
many aren't going to desire the Twitter server entrypoint for reasons
including dependencies, but also config management and bootstrap. Consider
netflixoss and others who use spring boot or other means to bootstrap
services. There's also the relative unpopularity of sbt within java
ecosystem, too!

It seems best to allow a java repo to exist regardless of Brave and just
move the corresponding issues there, right? I can count at least 3 folks
who would work on that and so it is more when than if.

Personally, this is of most interest to me as I like my work to be of
highest reuse, and I wish to engage those who have similar interest.
However this is more my morning/weekend work, like the work I did on Brave.
I still have to write Scala at work anyway.

Any reason we shouldn't just move this discussion to a new repo of willing
hands and let them decide what to do?

I tried this and it glitched out for reasons I don't recall. Glad you are
giving it another go!
@adriancole how did you discern between builder issues and #440? :)

umm.. basically there's flakey tests (ones that require services that flake
out), and massive (and conflicting) dep trees. This is independent of
builders, but makes builders easier?

Just to touch this again.

Inside Twitter, maven central is the preferred repo, and our pants 3rdparty will only look at that and https://maven.twttr.com/

I can manually push to the latter until central sync is supported. That would be ideally something that's already published to bintray. Once something is published somewhere, I can move twitter onto openzipkin, which would be very sweet.
looking at :8ball: to see if this build will pass
lgtm on green (and even if not green, I guess.. as long as it is not worse than before :))

Well, the build doesn't look _worse_ so that's something? #440 is still alive and well, these builds failed with:

```
[warn]     ::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
[warn]     ::              FAILED DOWNLOADS            ::
[warn]     :: ^ see resolution messages for details  ^ ::
[warn]     ::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
[warn]     :: io.netty#netty;3.10.1.Final!netty.jar(bundle)
[warn]     ::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
```

:crying_cat_face:

It's likely you'll run into [this issue](https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/3120), which I reported in January after trying this for Finagle. As far as I know it's not been fixed yet. If you're willing to remove `-Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true` from your `sbt` runner that should work as well.

@travisbrown I don't think I understand the pattern that links our build issues with the ones you link. We're not seeing JVMs crater, we're just seeing inconsistencies with the ability of a Travis builder to fetch the same dependency the N times the `sbt` build tries to grab it.
yanked for no good reason except yeah I can do this now.

@rtyler Right, I'm not claiming this is responsible for the current build issues—just that if you switch to the containerized build system, you'll get a buffer overflow if you call `getHostName` anywhere in your tests.

Having separate repos only really addresses client-side-A as far as i can see…

I'm rewriting zipkin-cassandra from scala to java, under the issue of replacing cassie with the datastax driver, simply because that's the contribution i can give (and it fits cleanly with the datastax driver). Since i can't imagine that this would then mean that the zipkin-cassandra subproject must be moved out into its own repo, along with progress on server-side-A, isn't it inevitable that zipkin becomes a mixture of java and scala? 

The question of sbt is a story for another day, in the server-side-B category.

so.. I am trying to just remove the repository references for started. Running what I think is clean process locally.

``` bash
# supernuke to redownload all the things
$ rm -rf ~/.sbt/staging/  ~/.ivy2/cache/ ~/.m2/repository
$ sbt clean test
```

I would prefer zipkin to just slowly introduce java where it makes sense.
If preference towards status quo (finagle/scala) interferes with that, I'd
prefer to make a repository in OpenZipkin or DistributedTracing to allow
progress to happen.

I don't expect all backends to be in a mono-repo, as especially people's
local implementations won't be (ex. inside Twitter, we have a Manhattan
storage backend). I don't really want to conflate this issue with the
mono-repo pros/cons though, but it is interesting that cassandra will be
rewritten in java anyway.

On SBT, our build really limits us, and this is only SBT because of scala.
I imagine there will be folks who would prefer to be more productive by
escaping that. Agreed it is another issue, but scala is related.
that worked.. will raise a PR
actually hold on.. testing that a related example still builds

Tested by building the example.

``` bash
$ cat ~/.sbt/0.13/global.sbt
publishTo := Some(Resolver.file("file",  new File(Path.userHome.absolutePath+"/.m2/repository")))
$ sbt publish
$ cd doc/examples/collector
$ sbt clean test
```

This issue is still rather unclear as to what it involves

If I've understood you correctly @adriancole you've asking for it to be about client-side-B, and that you'd like to see the work, these java interfaces that both brave and the tracer client library will inherit, in a new repo?

If this issue is to be solely about client-side-B then what about instead of creating a new repo, settle on using interfaces in Brave already? even migrate the scala+finagle implementation over to Brave so that it becomes the "driver" project to zipkin?

@michaelsembwever the issue as posted doesn't split hairs about client or server side, though I agree it would end up being broken down into work like that. I'm worried that I am dominating the discussion, and in attempts to answer in terms of the options you propose. server-side-B should be possible as an alternate or a rewrite.

We shouldn't conflate this issue with a vote for brave as ideal interfaces for client-side-A. Since this is a new community, it should be a choice how to implement client-side-(A|B), not a force function of current inventory.

We may get more engagement if the community are permitted to build both the server and client side in tandem in a manner they decide to, without the burden of a legacy codebase.

I'd like to hear what others think, and fear that further back/forth on my opinion may reduce the chance others will engage at all.

I don't remember off the top of my head why Finagle includes this setting—there is a reason, although I'm not sure it's applicable here.

For Finagle and related projects, I'm just waiting to move to the containerized build system until @travis-ci fixes this bug, but this is probably also a reasonable solution.

I don't know much about your build config, but if I remember correctly SBT won't put anything in `.m2` unless you're using the experimental (?) non-Ivy resolver.

One other thing you can try is putting `travis_retry sbt update` in a `before_script` script—this will retry resolution and downloading three times without adding retries the rest of the build.

finagle's unit tests assume that you've on ipv4–in particular, asking for localhost on ipv6 can give you one of four different results, but it's only one on ipv4.  finagle-memcached also spins up a real memcached, and we haven't gotten around to figure out how to get finagle to speak ipv4 to memcached when it's preferring ipv6.  I think zipkin once had a similar localhost issue, but my guess is that this is no longer the case, if tests pass reliably.
